title: French far right chief Bardella vows won't let 'Russian imperialism' absorb Ukraine
summary: In a debate on Thursday, the candidate of the Rassemblement National (RN) pledged both 'support for Ukraine and avoiding an escalation with Russia'. Tensions soared between supporters of Emmanuel Macron and the far right after its longtime leader Marine Le Pen cast doubt on the president's ability to act as head of the armed forces.

title: As Bardella becomes more like Macron, his party becomes more like Meloni's
summary: Jordan Bardella is trying to win over voters for Macron while also forging a new path for the far-right Rassemblement National that takes inspiration from Italy's Giorgia Meloni.

title: French elections poll: Far right holds large lead, with voters split in three blocs
summary: France's June 30 election looks set to confirm the far right's strength, while the left is struggling to catch up. President Emmanuel Macron's coalition, meanwhile, is lagging behind the other two blocs, according to an electoral survey conducted by Ipsos for Le Monde, the Fondation Jean Jaurès, Cevipof, Institut Montaigne, Radio France and France Télévisions.

title: Are the French becoming more racist?
summary: A report measuring yearly changes in French people's prejudice shows a 'significant and rare' decline in the 'tolerance index.'

title: 'Macron's room for maneuver on the European stage is likely to narrow, especially in the event of an RN victory'
summary: European Union leaders dread the idea of a French government in cohabitation with the far right. Such a scenario is indeed worrying on three counts: institutional, political and ideological, writes columnist Philippe Ricard.

title: Le Pen says president's role as commander-in-chief is 'honorary'
summary: Marine Le Pen claimed that a Rassemblement National prime minister would 'pull the strings' of French defense if her party achieves victory in the upcoming elections, even though the Constitution says the president is the 'head of the armed forces.'

title: EU leaders approve von der Leyen, Kallas and Costa for top jobs
summary: The late-night accord on Thursday carves up the bloc's top institutional jobs for the five years to come. At the side of Ursula von der Leyen, who heads the EU’s executive branch, are two new faces: Antonio Costa of Portugal as European Council president and Estonia’s Kaja Kallas as the top diplomat of the world’s largest trading bloc.

title: Portugal's António Costa, next president of the European Council
summary: The former Socialist prime minister will succeed Belgium's Charles Michel. At 62, Costa's moderate profile, combining traditional social-democratic values with an orthodox approach to the economy, won over the 27 member states.

title: Estonian Kaja Kallas named next European foreign minister
summary: The current liberal Prime Minister of Estonia will succeed the Spanish socialist Josep Borrell in the autumn. A staunch supporter of Ukraine in the face of Russia, she will have to deal with other issues and coexist with Ursula von der Leyen.

title: Former Uvalde school police chief and officer indicted over Robb Elementary response, reports say
summary: Pete Arredondo and Adrian Gonzales were indicted by a grand jury on multiple counts of felony child endangerment and abandonment, several news outlets reported on Thursday. The indictments would make the two men the first officers to face criminal charges in one of the deadliest school shootings in US history.

title: Bolivian police arrest former heads of army and navy over failed coup
summary: A total of 17 people have been arrested over their involvement in the coup attempt that shocked and baffled the country on June 26.

title: Israel lets 19 kids leave Gaza who are sick or wounded in first medical evacuation since May
summary: Israeli authorities say 68 people – 19 sick or wounded children plus their companions – have been allowed out of the Gaza Strip and into Egypt in the first medical evacuation since early May when the territory’s sole travel crossing was shut down after Israel captured it.

title: US Supreme Court allows emergency abortions in Idaho in limited ruling
summary: Thursday's ruling does not answer key questions about whether doctors can provide emergency abortions elsewhere, a pressing issue as some states have moved to restrict the procedure in the two years since the high court overturned Roe v. Wade.

title: Macron plans to back Thierry Breton to remain French EU commissioner
summary: Le Monde can reveal that French President Emanuel Macron was planning to tell his European Council counterparts about his decision on Thursday.

title: UK's Conservatives fear a historic defeat in the general election
summary: Lagging far behind Labour in the polls, and caught between the Liberal Democrats and Nigel Farage's far-right Reform party, the Tory party could be left with the smallest group in its history when the ballot boxes close on July 4.

title: US Supreme Court rejects divisive bankruptcy deal with OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma
summary: The $6 billion deal would have shielded the Sackler family who own the company from further liability over US opioid epidemic.

title: Man arrested with explosives near Paris airport was part of vast Russian sabotage campaign
summary: The 26-year-old Russian-Ukrainian was arrested in his hotel near Charles de Gaulle airport on June 3, after an accident while making explosives. He was planning to target a hardware store north of Paris, as part of a sabotage campaign orchestrated by Moscow.

title: Kenya's Ruto cracks down on protests, withdraws contested finance bill
summary: At least 22 people died in protests on Tuesday. as Kenyan President William Ruto faced the anger of young people taking to the streets over a budget that included tax hikes.

title: Paris 2024: Spain to send over 300 police to bolster Olympics' security
summary: The Spanish police will include bomb experts and sniffer dog teams and they will stay in Paris for both the Olympics and the Paralympics.

title: In the US, Stanford's disinformation observatory put on hold under Republican pressure
summary: The Californian university has not renewed the contract of this entity which tracked down false information about the 2020 presidential election and Covid-19 vaccines. Pro-Trump supporters, who accused it of censorship, have waged a ruinous legal battle against the observatory.
